20110125221612.000|20110125221615.000|TR0|Americans are feeling better about the 
20110125221615.000|20110125221617.000|TR0|state of that union than they have in 
20110125221617.000|20110125221619.000|TR0|almost four years.  A CNN Opinion Research 
20110125221619.000|20110125221622.000|TR0|Corporation poll shows 43 percent of those 
20110125221622.000|20110125221624.000|TR0|surveyed say things in the United States 
20110125221624.000|20110125221626.000|TR0|are going well.  That is a rather stunning 
20110125221626.000|20110125221629.000|TR0|14-point increase in just the last month.  
20110125221629.000|20110125221631.000|TR0|A majority, 56 percent, say things are 
20110125221631.000|20110125221633.000|TR0|still going badly, but that number is down 
20110125221633.000|20110125221636.000|TR0|sharply from 71 percent a month ago.
20110125221636.000|20110125221638.000|TR0|
20110125221638.000|20110125221640.000|TR0|The poll shows that college graduates and 
20110125221640.000|20110125221643.000|TR0|people in the Midwest are the most 
20110125221643.000|20110125221645.000|TR0|optimistic.  Also, urban and suburban 
20110125221645.000|20110125221647.000|TR0|Americans seem more optimistic than those 
20110125221647.000|20110125221650.000|TR0|in rural areas.  There's a partisan 
20110125221650.000|20110125221652.000|TR0|divide, too, as you might expect.  
20110125221652.000|20110125221655.000|TR0|Democrats and independents more likely to 
20110125221655.000|20110125221657.000|TR0|say things are going well than Republicans.
20110125221657.000|20110125221659.000|TR0|
20110125221659.000|20110125221702.000|TR0|So why the sharp increase, and why now?  
20110125221702.000|20110125221704.000|TR0|Well, the experts say part of the reason 
20110125221704.000|20110125221706.000|TR0|is the public's growing optimism about the 
20110125221706.000|20110125221709.000|TR0|economy. But there are some non-economic 
20110125221709.000|20110125221711.000|TR0|reasons at play here, as well.  People 
20110125221711.000|20110125221713.000|TR0|tend to be more optimistic at the start of 
20110125221713.000|20110125221716.000|TR0|a new year.  Other factors could include 
20110125221716.000|20110125221718.000|TR0|the more civil tone in political debate 
20110125221718.000|20110125221720.000|TR0|that has followed the Tucson shootings,

20110125222108.000|20110125222110.000|TR0|BLITZER:  Well, there's going to be a 
20110125222110.000|20110125222112.000|TR0|couple of tests coming up rather quickly 
20110125222112.000|20110125222115.000|TR0|in February and March, especially maybe by 
20110125222115.000|20110125222117.000|TR0|the end of March, when they have to raise

20110125223033.000|20110125223035.000|TR0|
20110125223035.000|20110125223037.000|TR0|JOE JOHNS, CNN CORRESPONDENT:  Well, Wolf, 
20110125223037.000|20110125223040.000|TR0|this is one of the most important 
20110125223040.000|20110125223042.000|TR0|questions you can possibly ask in 
20110125223042.000|20110125223044.000|TR0|politics.  It's a question politicians 
20110125223044.000|20110125223047.000|TR0|have been asking, a question we here at 
20110125223047.000|20110125223049.000|TR0|CNN have been asking a lot of our viewers. 
20110125223049.000|20110125223051.000|TR0| So we posed that question to the people 
20110125223051.000|20110125223054.000|TR0|in a poll, and we got some very 
20110125223054.000|20110125223056.000|TR0|interesting answers.
20110125223056.000|20110125223058.000|TR0|
20110125223058.000|20110125223101.000|TR0|And here's the way we posed it: "What 
20110125223101.000|20110125223103.000|TR0|would you cut?  What's more important, 
20110125223103.000|20110125223105.000|TR0|preventing cuts in Social Security or 
20110125223105.000|20110125223108.000|TR0|reducing the deficit?"  And the answer is 
20110125223108.000|20110125223110.000|TR0|clear, right there.  Seventy-eight percent 
20110125223110.000|20110125223113.000|TR0|said it's more important to prevent cuts 
20110125223113.000|20110125223115.000|TR0|in Social Security.
20110125223115.000|20110125223117.000|TR0|
20110125223117.000|20110125223120.000|TR0|We asked the same question of Medicare, 
20110125223120.000|20110125223122.000|TR0|and look at the results. Not even close.  
20110125223122.000|20110125223124.000|TR0|Eighty-one percent said preventing cuts in 
20110125223124.000|20110125223127.000|TR0|Medicare is more important than reducing 
20110125223127.000|20110125223129.000|TR0|the deficit.
20110125223129.000|20110125223131.000|TR0|
20110125223131.000|20110125223134.000|TR0|But there are some things we're told 
20110125223134.000|20110125223136.000|TR0|Americans would like to cut, and let's 
20110125223136.000|20110125223138.000|TR0|take a look at that.
20110125223138.000|20110125223141.000|TR0|
20110125223141.000|20110125223143.000|TR0|Among those things, foreign aid.  
20110125223143.000|20110125223145.000|TR0|Preventing cuts to foreign aid is OK.  
20110125223145.000|20110125223148.000|TR0|Eighteen percent said that would be more 
20110125223148.000|20110125223150.000|TR0|important than reducing the deficit.
20110125223150.000|20110125223152.000|TR0|
20110125223152.000|20110125223155.000|TR0|And the last question we posed to 
20110125223155.000|20110125223157.000|TR0|Americans there, what's more important, 
20110125223157.000|20110125223159.000|TR0|preventing cuts in government pensions?  
20110125223159.000|20110125223202.000|TR0|Thirty-nine percent said that's more 
20110125223202.000|20110125223204.000|TR0|important than 61 percent, who said 
20110125223204.000|20110125223206.000|TR0|reducing the deficit.
20110125223206.000|20110125223209.000|TR0|
20110125223209.000|20110125223211.000|TR0|So it's very clear Americans are 
20110125223211.000|20110125223213.000|TR0|conflicted.  They are not sure where to 
20110125223213.000|20110125223216.000|TR0|cut.  And when you look at things like 
20110125223216.000|20110125223218.000|TR0|foreign aid and pensions, that only makes 
20110125223218.000|20110125223220.000|TR0|up about four percent of spending.
20110125223220.000|20110125223223.000|TR0|
20110125223223.000|20110125223225.000|TR0|We did ask the question, Wolf, about the 
20110125223225.000|20110125223228.000|TR0|defense budget, and it was a split.  Fifty 
20110125223228.000|20110125223230.000|TR0|percent said you ought to cut it, 49 
20110125223230.000|20110125223232.000|TR0|percent said no.  Americans are tied when 
20110125223232.000|20110125223235.000|TR0|you look at the margin of error.  It's a 
20110125223235.000|20110125223237.000|TR0|very difficult thing to do.
20110125223237.000|20110125223239.000|TR0|
20110125223239.000|20110125223242.000|TR0|BLITZER:  All right.  Thanks very much.

20110125223359.000|20110125223401.000|TR0|that.
20110125223401.000|20110125223404.000|TR0|

20110125223406.000|20110125223408.000|TR0|something that people can do if they want

20110125223413.000|20110125223415.000|TR0|it does symbolizes, you know, that doing

20110125223418.000|20110125223420.000|TR0|this budget under control -- is no easy 
20110125223420.000|20110125223422.000|TR0|task.  And you're not going to have

20110125223458.000|20110125223500.000|TR0|PAUL:  Well, I mean, it's better than 
20110125223500.000|20110125223502.000|TR0|being more, you know, argumentative.  It 
20110125223502.000|20110125223505.000|TR0|sounds like there's a little bit of help, 
20110125223505.000|20110125223507.000|TR0|but I don't think it's going to do any 
20110125223507.000|20110125223509.000|TR0|good.       Sometimes when I see them 
20110125223509.000|20110125223512.000|TR0|bringing in, you know, CEOs of certain 
20110125223512.000|20110125223514.000|TR0|companies that are very much involved in 
20110125223514.000|20110125223516.000|TR0|the military industrial complex and big 
20110125223516.000|20110125223519.000|TR0|government, then that suggests to me that 
20110125223519.000|20110125223521.000|TR0|corporatism is alive and well for both the

20110125223530.000|20110125223533.000|TR0|

20110125223535.000|20110125223537.000|TR0|budget and balancing the budget.  That's 
20110125223537.000|20110125223540.000|TR0|very, very important, and I've never voted 
20110125223540.000|20110125223542.000|TR0|for an appropriation.  I don't vote for 
20110125223542.000|20110125223544.000|TR0|these budgets.  But more importantly is 
20110125223544.000|20110125223547.000|TR0|the size of the government.

20110125223551.000|20110125223554.000|TR0|policies, we have to have a smaller 
20110125223554.000|20110125223556.000|TR0|government.  We shouldn't over-concentrate 
20110125223556.000|20110125223559.000|TR0|on a balanced budget.
20110125223559.000|20110125223601.000|TR0|
20110125223601.000|20110125223603.000|TR0|You know, if we could cut our budget in 
20110125223603.000|20110125223606.000|TR0|half, and it wasn't balanced, it would be 
20110125223606.000|20110125223608.000|TR0|better than having today's budget 
20110125223608.000|20110125223610.000|TR0|balanced, because that would mean you'd 
20110125223610.000|20110125223613.000|TR0|have to raise a lot of taxes.  So I try my
